attributes.title: Online Stimuli Development and Testing
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

additionalComments.value: This pre-registration is intended to pre-register the central hypotheses of this study only. Additional pre-registration of supplemental correlational hypotheses and their corresponding data analysis plans will be forthcoming before data collection on this part of the larger study begins. These supplemental pre-registrations are related to variables in the second part of this study only (i.e., online survey and lab visit).

question2a.value:
With the focus group data, to answer RQ1 (for which they are no confirmatory hypotheses and analyses are exploratory), the independent variable is the stimuli / stimuli number. This variable is within-participants as focus group participant evaluate multiple stimuli per condition.

With the online survey and lab visit data, to test RQ2 and Hypothesis 2, the independent variable is condition (levels: race-related-negative, non-race-related-negative, non-race-related-positive). This variable is between-participants as participants are randomly assigned to see stimuli from one condition during the lab visit. Although the race-related-positive condition will not be compared to the other conditions, due to planned differences in the avatar (i.e., race-related-positive condition has stimuli with Black male avatars whereas other conditions have stimuli with a White male avatar; we did not believe the valence and racial motivation of the race-related-positive condition would be comparable to the other conditions if a White avatar was used), it will be examined separately in RQ3 (for which they are no confirmatory hypotheses and analyses are exploratory). In RQ3a, the independent variable is period (levels: baseline, stimuli-presentation), which is within-participants. In RQ3b, the independent variable is period (levels: baseline, recovery), which is within-participants. 

In RQ1-RQ2, these independent variables (stimuli number and condition) are treated as orthogonal as not every participant sees all stimuli from every condition. In RQ3, independent variables of period and stimuli/stimuli number are examined in different analyses and are thus treated as orthogonal.

question2b.value:
1) High-frequency heart rate variability (HF-HRV) indexed by the square root of mean squared differences in successive R-R intervals (RMSSD) following Hoggard, Hill, Gray, & Sellers, 2015. Using RMSSD is less susceptible to respiratory effects (Hill & Siebenbrock, 2009; Verkuil, Brosschot, & Thayer, 2014). This is an index of cardiac parasympathetic influence. Variable will be change in RMSSD from baseline physiological measurement to condition stimuli presentation physiological measurement (between-participant after this data reduction).

2) Stroke index (SI), which is stroke volume adjusted for body size (following Cooper et al., 2014). Stroke volume is the volume of blood pumped with each heartbeat. Variable will be change in SI from baseline physiological measurement to condition stimuli presentation physiological measurement (between-participant after this data reduction).

3) Cardiac index (CI; cardiac output adjusted for body size; Cooper et al., 2014). This is the volume of blood pumped per minute. Both #2 and #3 are proxies for the volume of blood pumped from the left ventricle and an indicator of cardiac function. Elevated cardiac output corresponds to early phases of hypertension (Palatini & Julius, 2009). Variable will be change in CI from baseline physiological measurement to condition stimuli presentation physiological measurement (between-participant after this data reduction).

4) Cardiac pre-ejection period (PEP). PEP is indexed as the time (in milliseconds) between left‐ventricular depolarization, indicated by onset of the ECG Q‐wave and the initiation of ejection of blood into the aorta, indicated by the ICG B-wave. Following Neblett & Roberts (2013), PEP is a general index of vascular contractility and a commonly accepted indicator of challenge or threat appraisals. Variable will be change in PEP from baseline physiological measurement to condition stimuli presentation physiological measurement (between-participant after this data reduction). 

5) Mean arterial pressure (MAP), which is a function of cardiac output and systemic vascular resistance (following Hill & Thayer, 2019). MAP is, generally, the average pressure in the arteries during one cardiac cycle and a good index of perfusion to vital organs (DeMers & Wachs, 2020). MAP can be derived from systolic and diastolic blood pressure measurements. Variable will be change in MAP from baseline physiological measurement to condition stimuli presentation physiological measurement (between-participant after this data reduction).

6) Change in self-reported emotion – pleasure dimension (measured by the Affect Grid; Russell, Weiss, & Mendelsohn, 1989) from pre-physiological measurement collection (i.e., baseline for emotion measurement) to post-physiological measurement collection (i.e., after exposure to condition stimuli) periods of the laboratory visit (between-participant after this data reduction).

7) Change in self-reported emotion – arousal dimension (measured by the Affect Grid; Russell, Weiss, & Mendelsohn, 1989) from pre-physiological measurement collection (i.e., baseline for emotion measurement) to post-physiological measurement collection (i.e., after exposure to condition stimuli) periods of the laboratory visit (between-participant after this data reduction).

These outcome variables are treated as orthogonal in the sense that they are examined separately in analyses (with Bonferroni correction). However, they would theoretically evidence significant correlations with one another if examined in the same analysis.

question3b.value: Covariates include: biological sex (Koenig & Thayer, 2016; Volpe, Lee, Hoggard, & Rahal, 2019), body mass index (Clark & Hill, 2009; Cooper et al., 2014; Hill, Hoggard, Richmond, Gray, Williams, & Thayer, 2017; Hoggard et al., 2015; Thayer, Yamamoto, & Brosschot, 2010; Tonhajzerova et al., 2008), caffeine (Pincomb et al., 1985) and/or nicotine use (Girdler et al., 1997), medication use (Collins et al., 2000; including any of the following cardioactive medications: cardiac medication, anxiety medication, medications that cause drowsiness, antidepressants, ADHD/ADD medication), physical activity (Hill, Hoggard, Richmond, Gray, Williams, & Thayer, 2017; Jackson et al., 1990), and experimenter (Schneiderman & McCabe, 1989).

question10b.value:
The study will consist of two parts that function as separate sub-studies with separate samples of participants - a focus group (Part 1) and an online survey and laboratory visit (Part 2). Part 1 consists of participants completing a focus group eligibility screener, which is an online Qualtrics survey. This survey first provides an electronic consent form for participants to review. Participants who consent then provide their contact information and intended compensation (gift card vs. participant pool credit), answers to eligibility questions previously described in inclusion/exclusion criteria (faculty status/undergraduate student status, race/ethnicity, age, and social media use), and preliminary availability (i.e., days of the week and morning/afternoon/evening) for focus group participation. If they meet eligibility criteria, participants will be emailed to schedule a time to come into the lab to participate in a focus group. Focus groups will be composed of a maximum of 6 students per focus group, with 2 focus groups per condition (race-related-negative, race-related-positive, non-race-related-negative, non-race-related-positive) and will be 60 minutes maximum. The condition that each focus group will assess will be randomly assigned (single-blind). Once they arrive to the lab for the focus group, participants will first re-engage in a written consent process. If electing to consent to participate, first participants will be asked to fill out a paper-and-pencil packet. This packet asks participants demographic questions (sex, gender identity, year in school, time spent on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, and Snapchat). It then asks participants to rate a set of 10 online social media stimuli (the set of stimuli for one of the four conditions) on a variety of dimensions, including perceived positivity, negativity, racial motivation, attractiveness of avatar, changes felt in their body when viewing the stimulus, and changes felt in their mood or thoughts when viewing the stimulus. Next, participants will be asked to discuss the group of stimuli together in a discussion format. Specifically, participants will view the group of stimuli on a TV screen and discuss which stimuli stuck out the most, are most stressful, are most negative, most positive, if they were racially motivated, their first impressions of the stimuli, and the realness of the stimuli. Participants will be compensated with a gift card of US $15 or psychology participant pool credit, debriefed, and provided with resources regarding stress and mental health. 

Part 2 will recruit a separate set of participants than Part 1 and consists of two components. First, interested participants will access an online survey on the Qualtrics platform. This survey provides information about the study and an opportunity to electronically consent to participate. Those participants who consent to participate in the study will provide their contact information and intended compensation (gift card vs. participant pool credit), answers to eligibility questions previously described in inclusion/exclusion criteria (participation in previous Part 1 of the study, faculty status/undergraduate student status, diagnosis of irregular heartbeat and/or heart rhythm, race/ethnicity, age, and social media use), and preliminary availability (i.e., days of the week and morning/afternoon/evening) for focus group participation. If they meet eligibility criteria, participants will next respond to a series of additional demographic questions (gender identity, sex, year in school, household income of the person who financially supports the participant). Then participants will respond to a series of standardized measures, which will be presented in a random order to participants, including: physical activity (following Jackson, Blaire, Mahar, Wier, Ross, & Stuteville, 1990), gender role conflict (GRC-SF; Wester, Vogel, O’Neil, & Danforth, 2012), exposure to traumatic events online (following Tynes, Willis, Stewart, & Hamilton, 2019), exposure to different forms of racism (IRRS-B; Utsey, Ponterotto, Reynolds, & Cancelli, 2000), exposure to individually experienced online racial discrimination (I-ORD following Tynes, Rose, & Williams, 2010), exposure to vicariously experienced online racial discrimination (V-ORD following Tynes, Rose, & Williams, 2010), critical consciousness (CCS; Diemer, Rapa, Park, & Perry, 2016), collective efficacy (following Cohen, Finch, Bower, & Sastry, 2006), social media use (Ohannessian, 2009; Vannucci, Flannery, & Ohannessian, 2017), racial identity (MIBI-S; Martin, Wout, Nguyen, Gonzalez, & Sellers, 2010), exposure to gendered racial microaggressions which will be completed only by cisgender women participants (GRMS; Lewis & Neville, 2015), exposure to and resilience against gender minority stress which will be completed only by transgender, gender non-binary, and/or agender participants (GMSRM; Testa, Habarth, Peta, Balsam, & Bockting, 2015). After completing questionnaires, participants will be provided with resources regarding stress and mental health, asked their preference for the sex of the research team member conducting their lab visit, and told they will be contacted about scheduling the lab visit via email soon. Participants will be compensated US $5 electronic gift card for completing the online survey. Participants will next attend the laboratory visit in a secure lab location on campus. Once they arrive to the lab, participants will first re-engage in a written consent process. If electing to consent to participate, the research assistant running the laboratory visit will first take measurements of participants’ body composition (height via stadiometer, weight via scale, waist circumference via a circumference measuring tape). Next, participants will be asked to complete a paper-and-pencil checklist which asks about caffeine consumption, nicotine consumption, cardiac medication, anxiety medication, medications that cause drowsiness, antidepressant medication, and ADHD/ADD medication. Then participants will complete a single-item measure of pleasure and arousal which asks participants to indicate how they are feeling “at this moment” by placing an X in one of the boxes on the grid (Affect Grid; Russell, Weiss, & Mendelsohn, 1989). Next, the research assistant will secure physiological equipment to the participant. Skin will first be prepared for single-use disposable ECG electrode placement by wiping the skin with preparation gel, which is slightly abrasive, and then electrodes are gel-ed with non-irritating, hypo-allergenic gel, and applied to the skin. Three electrodes will be placed on the skin – two on the left and right collarbone, respectively, and one on the lowest rib on the participant’s left side. A respiration belt will then be placed over the participant’s clothing around the abdomen/chest. Finally,  continuous non-invasive arterial pressure (CNAP) monitor equipment will be attached to the participant via the use of a finger and arm cuff. The participant will be asked to wear the ECG, respiration, and CNAP equipment for no more than 20 minutes in total. First, participants will engage in a baseline period wherein they will be instructed to sit still and relax without talking for 5 minutes. Next, participants will be shown a series of up to 10 online stimuli in the form of fabricated twitter posts on a computer screen. Participants will be randomized to see one set of 10 stimuli from one of the four stimuli conditions. Randomization to condition will be conducted by Inquisit programming such that condition will be double-blind. Before stimuli are presented, an attention-directing image will first appear on the screen. Each stimulus will be on the screen for 30 seconds (stimuli will be pre-programmed to display automatically for 30 seconds, one after the other), and the presentation of stimuli within condition will also be randomized via Inquisit programming. Finally, after participants have seen all stimuli in the set, they will engage in another period of 5 minutes (the “recovery” period) wherein they will be instructed to sit still and relax without talking for 5 minutes. After this period, physiological equipment will be removed. Next, participants will then be asked to fill out another paper-and-pencil packet, which includes another Affect Grid, question about emotions felt, a measure of racial centrality (sub-scale from MIBI-S), and questions about each stimuli avatar in the set (perceived race, perceived gender, perceived education, perceived attractiveness, perceived likeability) and manipulation check items (how racially motivated, positive, and negative were the stimuli as a group). Finally, participants will be compensated with a gift card of US $10 or psychology participant pool credit, debriefed, and provided with resources regarding stress and mental health.

question4b.value: Inclusion criteria for the study are as follows: 1) Participants must self-identify as Black (inclusive of African American, Caribbean Black, African, Afro-Latinx, and Bi-/multi-racial sub-categories), 2) Participants must be 18 years of age or older, 3) Participants must be undergraduate students at the university at which the data will be collected, and 4) Must use social media at least an hour per day. For the second part of the study (online survey and laboratory visit), exclusion criteria include a known diagnosed irregular heartbeat and/or heart rhythm. Participants who do not meet these inclusion/exclusion criteria will receive a message that they are ineligibile to participate in the study via the online survey or focus-group online prescreening eligibility questionnaire. Information beyond answers to these eligibility questions will not be collected from participants and therefore they will not have data on key variables to exclude from analyses. Their responses to eligibility questions will not count toward the sample size.

question5b.value: Data will be collected from Black undergraduate student participants recruited from one southeastern university in the United States. Data will be collected online via Qualtrics survey and in a secure laboratory location on campus (focus groups and lab visits). Focus group data will be collected from both paper-and-pencil packets and focus group discussion (from which data will be extracted from transcripts from de-identified audio recordings). Lab visit data will be collected via paper-and-pencil packets, research assistant measurements (e.g., weight, height, waist circumference) using medical/research devices, and physiological measurements that require participants to be hooked up to research equipment which passively, continuously, and non-invasively measures respiration, electrocardiogram, and arterial pressure monitor signals.

question6b.value:
RQ1. Planned sample size is 48 based on previous research which suggests a sample size of at least 6 participants for focus groups. Based on budget constraints, we will collect data from 48 participants total, with 2 focus groups per condition (4 conditions total).

RQ2. Minimum required sample size for power of .80 is 150 based on power analysis. See detailed power analysis attached.

RQ3. Minimum required sample size for power of .80 is 191 based on power analysis. See detailed power analysis attached.

However, for RQ2 and RQ3, we will collect data from 280 participants, in order to account for participant attrition from online survey to lab visit, equipment failures, and/or participant discontinuation, and in order to test supplemental correlational hypotheses (which will be pre-registered before data collection for part 2 of the study begins).

question7b.value:
On an individual participant basis, data collection will be terminated under the following conditions: 1) If the participant withdraws consent to participate at any time during the focus group, online survey (in this case termination rule would be automatic as the participant would just stop answering passive questions on the survey), and/or laboratory visit, 2) If the participant’s heart rate reaches 100bpm for more than 30 seconds during baseline or recovery, 160 bpm for more than 10 seconds during presentation of stimuli, or 3) if blood pressure reaches 180/120 mmHg for more than 30 seconds during baseline, presentation of stimuli, or recovery periods. Contingency protocols have been put in place for these scenarios. Additionally, in the case of fire, weather, or another unanticipated dangerous emergency situation data collection for a given participant may be terminated. 

On a full study basis, data collection will not be terminated until the proposed sample size is reached. The only exception that we anticipate at this time is if any unanticipated and/or adverse events (which will be reported to the IRB immediately) will result in an order to halt data collection (whether temporarily or long-term), in which case data collection will be suspended or terminated immediately. If a modification to the study protocol needs to be made based on formal or informal feedback from participants regarding the believability of the study that we did not already anticipate, we will plan to continue data collection, draft an IRB modification, and modify our protocol accordingly, noting which participants underwent data collection with the “old” versus “new” protocol. Given sufficient resources, this may also extend our data collection timeline and we may be able to achieve the originally proposed sample size with the “new” protocol, resulting in a total increase in the number of participants from which we collected data. However, we will NOT base the decision to extend data collection based on “pre-viewing” the data.

question8b.value:
a. Specific items/questions that are missing will not have values within the dataset, however participants may or may not be necessarily removed if they do not complete all questions because participants have the right to refuse to answer specific questions (with the exception of the eligibility questions). More specifically, entire participants and their subsequent scores will be removed in full from the data if the only questions that participants complete are the demographic and/or eligibility questions. In the lab visit, if experimenter and/or equipment failures occur, or if the participant chooses to discontinue participation such that continuous physiological data is not captured for all three of the measurement periods in full (baseline, stimuli presentation, and recovery), data for physiological measurements (MAP, PEP, SI, CI, HRV) will be examined with missing data analysis to determine what avenue is appropriate for the type of missing data present (i.e., MNAR, MAR, MCAR). In online survey and paper-and-pencil surveys in the lab visit, data will be examined with missing data analysis to determine what avenue is appropriate for the type of missing data present (i.e., MNAR, MAR, MCAR). 

b. In the online survey, failed attention checks on greater than or equal to 5% of scales with attention checks included will merit exclusion of all of the data for the online survey from that participant. In the instance of failed attention checks on less than 5% and greater than 0% of scales with attention checks included, scale scores itself for that scale will be removed. During the laboratory visit, if a participant indicates anything indicative of suspicion of the study hypotheses or their desire to provide socially desirable responses their entire laboratory visit data will be removed.

c. In terms of anticipated specific data exclusion criteria due to demographic exclusions, there are none beyond pre-specified inclusion/exclusion criteria described under “pre-selection rules”. Participants who do not meet these inclusion/exclusion criteria will receive a message that they are ineligibile to participate in the study via the online survey or focus-group online prescreening eligibility questionnaire. Information beyond answers to these eligibility questions will not be collected from participants and therefore they will not have data on key variables to exclude from analyses. Their responses to eligibility questions will not count toward the sample size. 

d. Outliers will be examined and removed based on established criteria: namely, by examining absolute values of studentized residuals for observations that exceed 3 (for which we can determine if the data point is influential by comparing the studentized residual to a t distribution with n-k-2 degrees of freedom where n = sample size and k = number of predictors), undue leverage of specific observations on the entire model via Cook’s D values that are greater than (4 / n-k-1) as indicated by Chatterjee & Hadi (1988), undue influence as indicated by Belsley, Kuh, & Welsch (1980) of specific observations on specific coefficient estimates via examination of absolute values of dffits values greater than (2*sqrt(Number of predictors – 1) / sample size), and of specific observations on the specific coefficient estimates via examination of dfbetas values greater than (2/square root(sample size)). We will take these measures for identifying outliers together to inform which outliers should be removed. More specifically, if an outlier is identified as such by Cook’s D, dffits, and dfbetas (all three) it will be removed. If an outlier is identified by studentized residuals and Cook’s D but does not appear to have much influence on the model via dffits and dfbetas, it will not be removed. In the event that an outlier violates one or more of these cutoffs, but does not violate Cook’s D, dffits, and dfbetas together, it will be retained but flagged for follow-up sensitivity analyses.

e. No method-based outlier criteria, beyond those related to equipment failure and/or 	experimenter error as described above, will be employed.

The only exception that we anticipate at this time is if any unanticipated and/or adverse events (which will be reported to the IRB immediately) will result in an order to halt data collection (whether temporarily or long-term), in which case data collection will be suspended or terminated immediately. If a modification to the study protocol needs to be made based on formal or informal feedback from participants regarding the believability of the study that we did not already anticipate, we will plan to continue data collection, draft an IRB modification, and modify our protocol accordingly, noting which participants underwent data collection with the “old” versus “new” protocol. Given sufficient resources, this may also extend our data collection timeline and we may be able to achieve the originally proposed sample size with the “new” protocol, resulting in a total increase in the number of participants from which we collected data. question6c.value: We will utilize Bonferroni corrections to correct for multiple comparisons, as indicated in each specific analysis plan.

question7c.value: Missing data will be handled with maximum likelihood estimation or multiple imputation, pending analysis of the type of missing data present (i.e., assuming missing data are MAR or MCAR).

question8c.value: Scale Cronbach’s alpha reliability must be .80 or greater to use the scale in analyses. We do not have any a priori criteria for item inclusion in a scale. We will follow analytic plans described previously to ensure stimuli within stimuli sets are reliable.

question9c.value: HRV data has been previously natural log transformed in order to normalize DV distributions (e.g., Hill, Hoggard, Richmond, Gray, Williams, & Thayer, 2017; Wagner, Lampert, Tennen,  & Feinn, 2013). However, other investigations that utilize change scores do not report any necessary transformations on HRV variables (e.g., Cooper et al., 2014). We will examine distributional assumptions of all DVs and transform if not sufficiently normal.

question10c.value:
Assumptions of multiple linear regression include: linear relationship between the outcome variable and independent variables, residuals are multivariate normal, independent variables are not highly correlated with one another, and variance of error terms are homoscedastic. Regression diagnostics will be conducted. Variable transformations and/or differential analytic parameterizations will be explored if assumptions of analyses are violated.

Assumptions of hierarchical/multilevel repeated measures analysis of variance (RMANOVA) include: assumptions of constant variances (homogeneity of variance, or homoscedasticity), constant covariances (compound symmetry), and constant variances of differences scores (sphericity). If these assumptions are violated, multilevel modeling will be explored as an analytic alternative.

question1a.value:
Step 1: Focus Group

RQ1. Which of our 40 stimuli should be tested in our subsequent study of physiological responses to online stimuli? More specifically, do the 10 stimuli per condition (4 conditions: positive-race-related, negative-race-related, positive-non-race-related, negative-non-race-related) demonstrate sufficient reliability and validity? 

Hypotheses: This analysis is exploratory. We do not make any a priori predictions about which of the 40 stimuli should be removed from the set and/or included in the set. However, our analytic plan details the criteria we will follow in establishing which stimuli should be removed or retained, using data from our mixed methods focus group data.

Step 2: Online Survey & Laboratory Visit

RQ2. Does exposure to condition (race-related negative vs. non-race-related negative vs. non-race-related positive) result in change in RMSSD, SI, CI, PEP, MAP, and emotion (pleasure, arousal)? Change is defined as change in reactivity from baseline for physiological measures and change from before physiological measurements to after physiological measurements for emotion measures. This question asks if the condition as a whole is significantly different and pools a score on each physiological outcome for each participant during the entire “stimuli presentation” period.

Hypothesis 2: Participants who view the race-related negative stimuli will evidence more marked change in physiological measures relative to participants who view the non-race-related negative and non-race-related positive stimuli. More specifically, we hypothesize that participants will evidence greater decreases in RMSSD from baseline, greater decreases in SI from baseline, greater decreases in CI from baseline, greater increases in PEP from baseline, greater increases in MAP from baseline, and increased arousal and decreased pleasure (emotional reactivity measures) from pre-physiological measurement (i.e., pre-stimuli presentation) to post-physiological measurement (i.e., pre-stimuli presentation) relative to participants who view the non-race-related negative and non-race-related positive stimuli.

RQ3. Exploratory examination of race-related-positive condition. Specifically, we will examine if : a) there are significant changes in reactivity to positive race-related stimuli (as a whole) from baseline, and b) if these changes persist into the recovery period. 

Hypotheses 3: Analyses are exploratory. No a priori hypotheses are provided. However, we will examine if each stimulus follows the same general pattern that we would anticipate for positive stimuli that is especially salient to one’s identity: an increase in RMSSD, increase in SI, increase in CI, decrease in PEP, and decrease in MAP to each stimulus presentation compared to baseline levels of these variables.

question2a.value: No interaction effects are hypothesized for central hypotheses listed above.

question3a.value: Participants will be asked to rate the group of stimuli that they observe in the lab visit in terms of a) positivity, b) negativity, and c) racial motivation. Successful manipulation checks predictions include: 1) Race-related negative and non-race-related negative conditions will be rated significantly more negative and less positive than race-related positive and non-race-related positive conditions, 2) Race-related negative and race-related positive conditions will be rated as significantly more racially motivated than non-race-related negative and non-race-related positive conditions.

question5a.value: The research is grounded in Tynes and colleagues’ (2018) Model of Online Racism and empirical work on online racism (e.g., Tynes, Willis, Stewart, & Hamilton, 2019; Keum & Miller, 2017; Volpe, Willis, Joseph, & Tynes, under review), which together suggest that online racism is a potent psychosocial stressor for people of color in the United States, particularly adolescents and young adults. Although no previous research has examined physiological responses to online racism, theoretical work proposes that online racism may engender psychosocial and corresponding psychophysiological stress responses, which has consequences for the health of Black individuals (Volpe, Hoggard, Willis, & Tynes, under review). However, we operate from the assumption that exposure to online racism engenders a physiological stress response similar to exposure to in-person racism (or its proxies, as measured experimentally). The Biopsychosocial Model of Racism (Clark, Anderson, Clark, & Williams, 1999) provides the overarching theoretical framework for asserting that exposure to racism engenders a physiological stress response. Following this work, the Neurovisceral Integration Model (Thayer & Friedman, 2004; Thayer & Lane, 2009) provides additional support for our predictions regarding heart rate variability. Furthermore, previous investigations have found Black samples to evidence physiological patterns of increases in PEP and decreases in HRV (e.g., Hill, Richmond, Hoggard, Gray, Williams, & Thayer, 2017; Hoggard, Hill, Gray, & Sellers, 2015; Neblett & Roberts, 2013) and decreases in stroke volume and cardiac output and increases blood pressure (Armstead, Lawler, Gorden, Cross, & Gibbons, 1989; Blascovich, Spencer, Quin, & Steele, 2001; Clark, 2006; Clark, Cobb, Hopkins, & Smith, 2006; Clark & Hill, 2009; Cooper, Thayer, & Waldstein, 2014; McNeilly et al., 1996; Merritt, Bennett, Williams, Edwards, & Sollers, 2006; Morris-Prather, Harrell, Collins, Leonard, Boss, & Lee, 1996), indicative of increased physiological stress response, when exposed to racism. In terms of emotional outcomes, the Biopsychosocial Model of Racism (Clark et al., 1999) posits that exposure to racism may engender increases in negative affect and arousal, which is supported by empirical work which finds increases in negative affect in response to exposure to racism in the laboratory setting (Hoggard, Jones, & Sellers, 2017) and research and theorizing on racism-related stress in general (Carter et al., 2013; Harrell, 2000).

question6a.value: It is worth noting that some studies have found that perceived racism (assessed via self-report) is associated with changes in systolic but not diastolic blood pressure in samples of Black college students (e.g., Clark, 2006; Volpe, Rahal, Holmes, & Zelaya Rivera, 2018). However, the current investigation is experimental rather than correlational and we are particularly examining MAP as an overall index of blood pressure reactivity rather than systolic versus diastolic blood pressure alone, therefore we do not posit multiple predictions for the same IV-DV combination.

question1c.value: RQ1 – Focus Group (No a priori hypotheses, exploratory): See below (statistical technique) for full details.

question2c.value:
RQ1 – Focus Group (No a priori hypotheses, exploratory):

Before the primary analyses are run on the data, variables collected from the online screener survey will be examined in order to use the frequency and descriptive statistics to describe our focus group sample demographically and in terms of their social media use. The demographic variables are age, sex assigned at birth on one’s original birth certificate, current gender identity, race/ethnicity, and year in school. Social media use will be evaluated using four questions that ask how much time a participant spends on Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, and Facebook, respectively, which will be measured on a 6-point scale that ranged from 1 (None) to 6 (About four hours). 

Analytic evaluation of the original stimuli set will then occur in several steps. First, interrater reliability will be determined using two intraclass correlation (ICC) analyses. We will use a two-way random effects model assessing single measure consistency in quantitative ratings of three qualities of interest, positivity, negativity, and racial motivation, for each of the four stimuli conditions.  The threshold for acceptable consistency will be an ICC of at least 0.70 (Landis & Koch, 1977). Our goal is to have an average ICC of at least 0.70 for each condition.

If a stimuli set has adequate ICC’s for all three main qualities of  interest, meaning that the whole stimuli set was consistently rated on positivity, negativity, and racial motivation, each Tweet stimulus’ will be further examined in order to determine exclusion or inclusion within the final stimuli set. Mean scores for the qualities of interest will be used as a primary step to indicate whether or not participants’ perceptions of individual stimuli match the intended condition. For the race-related positive condition, the desired mean score for positivity will be at least 4 (Very Positive), at most 2 (Slightly Negative) for negativity, and at least 4 (Very Racially Motivated) for racial motivation. For the non-race-related-negative condition, the desired mean score for positivity will be at most 2 (Slightly Positive), at least 4 (Very Negative) for negativity, and at least 4 (Very Racially Motivated) for racial motivation. For the non-race-related-positive condition, the desired mean score for positivity will be at least 4 (Very Positive), at most 2 (Slightly Negative) for negativity, and at most 2 (Slightly Racially Motivated) for racial motivation. For the non-race-related-negative condition, the desired mean score for positivity will be at most 2 (Slightly Positive), at least 4 (Very Negative) for negativity, and at most 2 (Very Racially Motivated) for racial motivation. The scale cutoffs for the quality of interest mean scores were determined using Larsen et al.’s (2009) description of positive and negative unipolar scale scores in their validated evaluative space grid. 

For the stimuli within each condition that meet these mean requirements, there will be a final step to determine inclusion dependent upon the three qualities of interest. The qualitative responses to the questions, “Of all of these tweets, which are the most negative?,” “What was most negative about it / why was it most negative?,” “Which are the most positive?,” ”What was most positive about it / why was it most positive?,” “How racially motivated did you think these tweets were?,” and “How could you tell?” will be used in this step. The focus group discussion will be recorded. Participants will be instructed to speak one at a time and to state their participant ID number before responding to any question or statement posed during the discussion. During transcription of the discussions, these ID numbers will be used to differentiate participant responses. If there is at least 30% disagreement from focus group participants about an intended quality of interest, the stimulus in question will be removed from the final stimuli set. So, for example, if at least four participants across a condition’s two focus groups, or approximately 30% of these focus group participants, do not believe or question whether a stimulus from the race-related-positive condition is positive, it will be removed for not adequately fitting with its condition. These steps will be taken so that we can make sure that the stimuli that are included do in fact represent the conditions for which they were designed. 

If a stimuli set does not have adequate ICCs (i.e., defined as being below 0.70, for all three qualities of interest), meaning that there was not consistency in quantitative ratings of the stimuli set, the qualitative responses about these qualities will be used to determine which stimuli to remove from the set. Therefore, as stated above, if there is at least 30% disagreement or more than four participants who disagree about an intended quality of interest regarding a stimulus within one of the conditions, that stimulus will be removed from the final stimuli set. After all stimuli that do not pass through the qualitative step are removed, ICC analyses on the qualities of interest for the updated stimuli set will be run again. The stimuli sets will then go through the previously stated steps dependent upon whether their quality of interest ICCs are below or above the set threshold, 0.70.

Once consistently rated and evaluated stimuli sets are established dependent upon qualities of interest, further examination of the stimuli within each condition will occur. The following steps will be carried out concurrently. The 30% or four participant threshold for disagreement within the intended conditions written about previously will also be used in this set of steps to determine if a stimulus should be removed from its condition. In one step, responses to the following questions from the questionnaire will be examined, “When looking at this post, do you feel any changes happening to your body? (Select one option, Yes or No)  If so, please briefly explain:” and “When looking at this post, do you feel any changes in your mood or thoughts? (Select one option, Yes or No)  If so, please briefly explain:”. For the participants that select yes, their open-ended responses will be examined by the research team to determine whether the changes that they write about are incongruent with the intended condition or speak to a quality of the stimulus that would not be desirable for the final stimuli set. For example, in an examining a race-related-negative stimulus, if four participants indicate that the stimulus is funny or that it makes them want to laugh, that stimulus will be removed from the stimuli set. In another step, responses to the following questions from the discussion will be examined dependent upon whether the condition is positive or negative, “Of all of these tweets, which are the most stressful?” and “What was most stressful about it / why was it stressful?.” For the race-related-positive and non-race-related-positive conditions, it is preferred that they are overall not stressful for the participants. For the race-related-negative and non-race-related-negative conditions, it is preferred that they are overall stressful for the participants. In another step, responses to the following questions from the discussion will be examined to determine believability of the stimuli, “Did you think these were real Twitter statuses?,” “Why or why not?,” “Is there anything we could do to make them more believable?,” and “What things did you notice while looking at them?” In this step, stimuli that are not considered to be believable will not necessarily abide by the previously stated exclusion threshold. The final decision for the stimulus in question will be determined by the research team. If there is a stimulus that does not meet the threshold for believability, but maps well onto its intended condition, the research team may decide to include it within the final stimuli set if the other quantitative and qualitative responses about stimulus quality are thought to outweigh its lack of believability. 

As a final step for evaluating the stimuli for inclusion within the final stimuli set, the responses to the discussion questions, “Which one of these tweets stuck out to you the most?,” and “Why did it stick out to you?” will be examined. Ideally, the stimuli within the final set will not be uniquely different from others within the same condition. If they were, any responses to the condition within experimental studies may be due to the unique stimulus and not the intended qualities of the condition. The exclusion threshold will not be the basis for exclusion in this step. The research team will closely examine responses to the second question. If the responses about certain stimuli indicate a unique quality of the stimulus in question that is determined to be potentially detrimental to the quality of final stimuli set, it will be removed. 

Other than being used for determining whether a stimulus will be included or excluded, the qualitative responses from the questionnaire and discussion will be used to later describe the stimuli within any future publications or presentations.

question3c.value: RQ1 – Focus Group (No a priori hypotheses, exploratory): See above (statistical technique) for full details.

question1c.value: RQ3 – Online Survey & Laboratory Visit (Hypotheses 3; No a priori hypotheses; Exploratory): For RQ3a, relevant variables include period (within-person; 2 levels: baseline, stimuli-presentation) 5 outcome variables (change in HRV, SI, CI, MAP, PEP), and theoretically-based control variables of  biological sex, BMI, caffeine and/or nicotine use, medication use, physical activity, and experimenter (listed with supporting citations below).  For RQ3b, relevant variables include period (within-person: 2 levels: baseline, recovery), 7 outcome variables (change in HRV, SI, CI, MAP, PEP, emotion – arousal, emotion - pleasure), and theoretically-based control variables of  biological sex, BMI, caffeine and/or nicotine use, medication use, physical activity, and experimenter (listed with supporting citations below). Biological sex, caffeine and/or nicotine use, medication use, and physical activity will be measured via self-report survey measures. Experimenter running the laboratory visit will be recorded by the research team. BMI will be calculated from experimenter measurements of participant height and weight during the laboratory visit. Measurement of outcome variables is via physiological equipment (change in HRV, SI, CI, MAP, PEP) and self-reports on the Affect Grid (change in emotion-arousal and emotion-pleasure), as described in the previous “Essential elements – Hypotheses” and its subsequent “Dependent Variables” section. Change scores in DVs are calculated before analyses as part of data reduction efforts.

question2c.value: RQ3 – Online Survey & Laboratory Visit (Hypotheses 3; No a priori hypotheses; Exploratory): Preliminary analyses will begin with assessment of linear regression model assumptions (e.g., normality). If necessary, DV data will be transformed to meet model assumptions. Preliminary analyses will also include empirical examination of theoretically-proposed control variables. If control variables are not found to be significantly associated with DVs using bivariate correlation analysis, they will not be retained in analyses investigating the central hypothesis. Finally, RQ3a and RQ3b will each be tested with 5 (one for each DV) hierarchical/multilevel repeated measures analysis of variance (RMANOVA) models which incorporate control variables, with Bonferroni corrections to account for multiple comparisons.

Control variables are biological sex, BMI, caffeine and/or nicotine use, medication use, physical activity, and experimenter.

question1c.value: RQ2 – Online Survey & Laboratory Visit (Hypothesis 2): Relevant variables include: condition (randomized; double-blind; 3 levels: negative-race-related, negative-non-race-related, and positive-non-race-related), 7 outcome variables (change in HRV, SI, CI, MAP, PEP, emotion – arousal, emotion - pleasure) and theoretically-based control variables of  biological sex, BMI, caffeine and/or nicotine use, medication use, physical activity, and experimenter (listed with supporting citations below). Biological sex, caffeine and/or nicotine use, medication use, and physical activity will be measured via self-report survey measures. Experimenter running the laboratory visit will be recorded by the research team. BMI will be calculated from experimenter measurements of participant height and weight during the laboratory visit. Measurement of outcome variables is via physiological equipment (change in HRV, SI, CI, MAP, PEP) and self-reports on the Affect Grid (change in emotion-arousal and emotion-pleasure), as described in the previous “Essential elements – Hypotheses” and its subsequent “Dependent Variables” section. Change scores in DVs are calculated before analyses as part of data reduction efforts.

question2c.value: RQ2 – Online Survey & Laboratory Visit (Hypothesis 2): Preliminary analyses will begin with assessment of linear regression model assumptions (e.g., normality). If necessary, DV data will be transformed to meet model assumptions. Preliminary analyses will also include empirical examination of theoretically-proposed control variables. If control variables are not found to be significantly associated with DVs using bivariate correlation analysis, they will not be retained in analyses investigating the central hypothesis. Finally, simultaneous multiple linear regressions (one for each DV; 7 DVs; Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons will be applied) will be run to test the central hypothesis (i.e., planned contrast). More specifically, we will use an orthogonal planned contrast to compare negative race-related to the other two conditions (race-related-negative vs. non-race-related-negative and non-race-related-positive).

Change in MAP, HRV, SI, CI, PEP, emotion-arousal, and emotion-pleasure are the DVs (examined in separate regression analyses with Bonferroni correction). Control variables are biological sex, BMI, caffeine and/or nicotine use, medication use, physical activity, and experimenter.
