attributes.title: Infidelity Behaviours - Follow up study
attributes.description: In a follow up study, we will try to understand if undergraduates' evaluation of a list of infidelity behaviours have changed after 10 years.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: 10 year follow up study-Understanding infidelity behaviours.

other.value:
As stated in first question, data collection began on January 27, 2020. We have not downloaded the data yet. However, will need to export the data from the survey around mid-Feburary 2020 so that we can analyze the data for the purpose of a research course that must be completed by the end of the winter 2020 term (i.e., two students are conducting this study for research courses in which they are enrolled and must submit final papers for these courses in the middle of April 2020). The data collection will continue after that point, however, until we have reached the desired sample size of 400 (aiming for approximately equal sample sizes for men and women). 
N.B. Any results pertaining to the hypotheses and research questions identified in this pre-registration that we publish or present will be based on the final sample, not the interim sample downloaded for purposes of the course requirements.

sample.value: We aim to collect data from 400 participants. We have multiple predictors and the infidelity questionnaire includes 64 items. A sample size of 400 will provide enough statistical power to investigate the relationship between variables and judgements of infidelity while allowing for the examination of possible sex differences.

analyses.value:
It should be mentioned that for infidelity incidence and partner’s engagement in infidelity behaviours, participants indicate whether they or their partner have engaged in extradyadic behaviours by choosing yes or no options for each behaviour. Therefore, the infidelity incidence and partner’s engagement in infidelity behaviours will be calculated in one of the following forms: 1) to be coded as yes/no (e.g., if they’ve engaged in any of the behaviours, they get a 1 for yes) or 2) a proportion (e.g., if there are 10 behaviours and they’ve engaged in 5 of them they get a .5) or c) a count (e.g., if there are 10 behaviours and they’ve engaged in 5 they get a 5). We may change the type of analysis incorporating these variables based on the way we decide to treat these variables. But for the purpose of this application, we present the analysis as we treat these variables as dichotomous (yes/no). 
A  2 participants’ gender (men and women) × 2 timepoints (2009 and 2020) × 5 types of extradyadic behaviours mixed method ANOVA will be used to test the differences between severity ratings from 2020 data and 2009 data.
Loglinear analysis will be used to compare infidelity incidence rates in 2009 and 2020 based on gender (RQ2).
We will conduct a 2 timepoint (2009 vs 2020) × 2 participants’ gender (men vs women) between-subject ANOVA to investigate differences between men’s and women’s sociosexuality scores in 2020 and 2009 (RQ3). 

Hierarchical multiple regression analysis will be used to investigate how well the various individual difference measures predict severity ratings, controlling for gender of the participant (H1). Gender will be entered in step one and all the predictors will be included in step two. 
Logistic regression analysis will be used to investigate how well the various individual difference measures predict infidelity incidence, controlling for the gender of the participants (H2).  Gender will be entered in step one and all the predictors will be included in step two. 

Simple mediation, using the PROCESS macro, or SEM (structural equation modeling) will be used to test whether use of monogamy maintenance strategies mediates the relationship between commitment and infidelity incidence (RQ4) with gender as a covariate. 

We will conduct a 2 participants’ sex (man vs women) × 2 sex of the extradyadic partner (same vs opposite) × 5 types of extradyadic behaviours mixed method ANOVA to investigate differences in severity ratings based on participants’ sex and extradyadic partners’ sex. 


Logistic regression will be used to test whether honesty humility moderates the association between sociosexual orientation and infidelity incidence, controlling for gender of the participants (H6).

The associations in RQ5 and RQ6 will be investigated using simple Pearson correlation (for two continuous variables) or Chi square (for two categorical variables).

outliers.value:
Participants who report they have never been involved in a romantic relationship will be removed from the analysis. 
Additionally, we asked a self-report response data quality question at the end of the study in 2020 in which participants are asked to indicate whether we ought to keep their data given the attention and effort they put into completing the survey. We will exclude the data from any participant who reports lack of attention (i.e., who responds “no”). 
Also, at the end of the survey in 2020, we ask participants for their permission to retain the data for use in our analyses. We will delete their data if they choose not to let us use their data.
After excluding data based on above criteria, we will run our analysis both with and without outliers. We will report whether the results differ in any publications and presentations. Outliers will be identified by computing the overall standard deviation and removing any outliers beyond 3.0 SD above/below the mean.

dependent.value:
In the current study, we will present 64 extradyadic behaviours to participants and will ask them to:

·	Indicate whether they would consider the behaviour to be unfaithful or cheating if an individual in a serious committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviours with a person of the opposite sex.
·	Rate the severity for each of the behaviors assuming a partner in a serious, committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviors with an opposite sex partner.
·	Indicate whether they would consider the behaviour to be unfaithful or cheating if an individual in a serious committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviours with a person of the same sex.
·	Rate each behavior for severity if a partner in a serious, committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviors with a same sex partner.
·	Check any of the behaviors they have engaged in with someone other than their partner while in a serious committed relationship (either a prior relationship or their current relationship).
·	Check any of the behaviors that a partner in a serious, committed relationship with them has engaged in with someone else (either in a prior relationship or their current relationship).

hypothesis.value:
The current research is a follow up to another study that was done 10 years ago (2009). In that study, we presented 53 extra-dyadic behaviours to participants and asked them to:

·	Indicate whether they would consider the behaviour to be unfaithful or cheating if an individual in a serious committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviours with a person of the opposite sex.
·	Rate the severity for each of the behaviors assuming a partner in a serious, committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviors with an opposite sex partner.
·	Indicate whether they would consider the behaviour to be unfaithful or cheating if an individual in a serious committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviours with a person of the same sex.
·	Rate each behavior for severity if a partner in a serious, committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviors with a same sex partner.
·	Check any of the behaviors they have engaged in with someone other than their partner while in a serious committed relationship (either a prior relationship or their current relationship).
·	Check any of the behaviors that a partner in a serious, committed relationship with them has engaged in with someone else (either in a prior relationship or their current relationship).
One major goal of the current study is to investigate how much people’s answers to these questions have changed after 10 years. The main reason we expect we might see changes in how people perceive extra-dyadic behaviours (i.e., how severe they perceive them) and how much they engage in the behaviours is related to changes in technology. Increasing use of smartphones in the past decade, the prevalence of dating applications and websites such as Tinder, and new ways of sending text messages such as direct messaging on social media or messaging applications might have influenced how people perceive and engage in extra-dyadic behaviours (e.g. by providing new media or platforms with which to engage in infidelity). 

For the same reason, we included more online and technology-related items (i.e., behaviours) in our follow up study to make our list of possible extradyadic behaviours more comprehensive. To decide which items from the list of 53 behaviours to keep and which to discard for the follow-up, we presented the 53 behaviours to participants in a study in 2019 and asked them to make the same judgements as participants did in the 2009 study. Based on the results of this study, we dropped the behaviours that fewer than 10 percent of participants in the 2019 study identified as infidelity and replaced them with (a) new online and technology-related behaviours and (b) several behaviours that other researchers identified in their studies during the ten years since our 2009 study (i.e., those not included in our previous list). Combined, this process resulted in an updated list including 64 extradyadic behaviours that we will use in the current follow up study. 

In the 2019 study, we also asked participants to sort the 53 behaviours into categories (via a card sort task). We will use the results of a cluster analysis performed on these data to categorize the behaviours in the present study so that we can run our analyses on the infidelity categories instead of each behaviour separately (thereby reducing the number of statistical tests we will need to perform). The four categories that emerged from the card sort task are (1) sexual behaviours, (2) emotional behaviours, (3) ambiguous behaviours (such as doing a favour for someone or spending time with them) , and (4) others (we haven’t found a label that captures the range of items in this category so we might change the name of the category if we find a suitable name). The behaviours in the follow up study will be classified into the same categories plus an additional category for online behaviours. However, we might change the categories if the results of reliability tests show that the items in the same category are not coherent. 

In the follow up study (the current research), we will present the list of 64 extra-dyadic behaviours to our participants and ask them to make the same judgements as participants in the 2009 study did. Our hypotheses and research questions are presented below. For each hypothesis or set of related hypotheses a rationale that supports anticipated direction is presented. Also, in the following sections, participants’ own engagement in extradyadic behaviours will be referred to as “infidelity incidence” ,their ratings of perceived severity of the extradaydic behaviours will be referred to as “severity ratings”, and their partners’ engagement in extradyadic behaviours will be called “partner’s engagement in extradyadic behaviours.”

Research question 1) Will severity ratings for the various types of infidelity in the current study differ from severity ratings in the study in 2009? We will examine the difference across timepoints for the sample as a whole, as well as incorporating gender of participant and gender of extradyadic partner into the analysis.

Research question 2) Will the reported incidence of different types of infidelity reported in the current study differ from the reported incidence of infidelity in 2009? We will examine the difference across timepoints for the sample as a whole, as well as incorporating gender of participant into the analysis.

Research question 3) Will partner engagement in different types of infidelity reported in the current study differ from reported partner engagement in infidelity in 2009? We will examine the difference across timepoints for the sample as a whole, as well as incorporating gender of participant into the analysis.


Research question 4) Do 2020 participants differ from 2009 participants in their mean score on sociosexuality? We will examine the difference across timepoints for the sample as a whole, as well as incorporating gender of participant into the analysis.


Hypothesis 1) Controlling for possible gender differences, higher severity ratings will be associated with: 1) higher attachment anxiety, 2) higher honesty-humility (HH), 3) higher jealousy, 4) lower attachment avoidance, 5) lower infidelity incidence, 6) more restricted sociosexual orientation. 

Hypothesis 2) Controlling for possible gender differences, higher infidelity incidence will be associated with: 1) higher attachment anxiety, 2) higher attachment avoidance, 3) more unrestricted sociosexual orientation, 4) higher quality of alternatives, 5) lower HH, 6) lower commitment, 7) lower relationship satisfaction, 8) lower investment size.

Rationale for hypotheses 1 and 2:

With regards to honesty humility, results of a study by Bourdage, Lee, Ashton, and Perry (2007) show that higher honesty-humility is positively correlated with relationship exclusivity. Based on this evidence, we hypothesized that since people with high honesty humility value relationship exclusivity, they will tend to rate infidelity behaviours more severe and engage in infidelity behaviours less often than people who are low in honesty humility. 

Research shows that attachment insecurity can be a predictor of engaging in infidelity, and therefore we hypothesized that higher attachment insecurity (both anxious and avoidant) is associated with higher infidelity incidence. However, the predicted association between attachment insecurity and severity ratings differs based on the type of attachment insecurity. This anticipated difference is related to perceived levels of threat in anxious vs avoidant individuals.  Anxious individuals are prone to overestimate threats to their romantic relationship (Collins, 1996) and they experience more jealousy in comparison to less anxious individuals (Buunk, 1997; Guerrero, 1998; Radecki-Bush, Farrell, and Bush, 1993; Sharpsteen and Kirkpatrick, 1997). Therefore, we expected higher severity ratings for anxious participants. 
In contrast, avoidant individuals show low levels of concern about the threat of a rival (Guerrero, 1998; Sharpsteen and Kirkpatrick, 1997). In current study, we expect that highly avoidant individuals will perceive lower levels of threat when evaluating extradyadic behaviours and therefore, they will score low on severity ratings. 

In addition, research shows that people with unrestricted sociosexual orientation tend to perceive extradyadic behaviours as less indicative of infidelity in comparison to people with more restricted sociosexual orientation (Mattingly, Wilson, Clark, Bequette, & Weidler, 2010) which is consistent with our anticipated direction of the relationship between severity ratings and sociosexual orientation. Unrestricted sociosexual orientation is also a facilitator of engaging in infidelity (Fincham and May, 2016. Therefore, we anticipated that participants with unrestricted sociosexual orientation would report higher rates of infidelity incidence.

We also hypothesized that a high level of jealousy might lead people to perceive extradyadic behaviours as more threatening and, therefore, that we will find an association between increasing jealousy and higher scores on severity ratings.

Our hypotheses regarding the Investment Model variables are based on previous research indicating that people with lower relationship commitment, lower relationship satisfaction, lower investment size, and higher quality of alternatives tend to consider extradyadic behaviours as infidelity to a lower degree (Mattingly, Wilson, Clark, Bequette, & Weidler, 2010) and to report higher rates of engaging in infidelity (Drigotas, Safstrom, & Gentilia, 1999; Fincham and May, 2016).. 

Finally, previous infidelity experience predicts future engagement in infidelity (Fincham and May, 2016). Based on this evidence, we hypothesized that people who have engaged in extradyadic behaviours will evaluate them as less severe than people who have not engaged in such behaviours and that might partially explain why they tend to engage in the infidelity more often in the future. 

Research question 4) Does the use of monogamy maintenance strategies predict infidelity incidence and if so, is this relationship mediated by any of the investment model variables and does it hold equally for both genders?


Hypothesis 3) men will perceive sexual infidelity as less severe when their partner engages in it with a same- rather than opposite-sex extra-dyadic partner.

Hypothesis 4) Women’s ratings of the perceived severity of sexual infidelity will not vary as a function of the gender of the extra-dyadic partner.

We hypothesized that male participants would judge sexual extra-dyadic behaviours less severe if their partner engaged in these behaviours with a same- rather than opposite-sex partner because women’s same-sex sexual contact poses no threat to paternity certainty and is portrayed in pornography as sexually arousing for men. We predicted that gender of the extra-dyadic partner would not influence perceived severity of infidelity behaviours among women since the threat that the partner might divert resources to another may be equally high regardless of the gender of the EDP.

Hypothesis 5) in both studies (2009 and 2020) men will report higher rates of engaging in infidelity than women. 

Several studies show that men report higher rates of infidelity than women   (e.g., Atkins et al., 2001; Buunk & Bakker, 1995; Choi et al., 1994; Treas & Giesen, 2000; for a meta-analysis, see Petersen & Hyde, 2010).


Hypothesis 6) The relationship between sociosexual orientation and infidelity incidence will be moderated by HH, such that those with unrestricted sociosexual orientation who are also low in HH will be more likely to report having engaged in extradyadic behaviours than people who score high on both variables. We will include gender of participant in this analysis. 

Research shows that an unrestricted attitude toward sex is one of the predictors of infidelity incidence (Fincham and May, 2016). Research also indicates that higher HH scores are associated with higher relationship exclusivity (Bourdage et al., 2007). Therefore, people who are unrestricted in their sociosexual orientation might engage in extradyadic behaviours less if they score high on HH (in comparison those who are sociosexually unrestricted and low on honesty humility). 

Research indicates that higher HH scores are associated with higher relationship exclusivity (Bourdage et al., 2007), so we are predicting that high HH might serve to inhibit, to some extent, those with an unrestricted sociosexual orientation from engaging in infidelity compared with those who are both unrestricted and low in HH (and therefore not much inclined to worry about  relationship exclusivity).

Research question 5) Are reports of a partner’s engagement in extradyadic behaviours associated with 1) severity ratings, 2) relationship satisfaction, 4) jealousy, 5) investment size, 6) relationship commitment, and 7) quality of alternatives?

Research question 6) We will explore possible associations between a) jealousy and infidelity incidence, b) the investment model variables (commitment, investment size, quality of alternatives, relationship satisfaction) and severity ratings, e) infidelity incidence (i.e., participants’ own reports of having engaged in extradyadic behaviours) and (their reports of) partner’s engagement in extradyadic behaviours.

The data collection will continue after that point, however, until we have reached the desired sample size of 400 (aiming for approximately equal sample sizes for men and women). 
N.B. Any results pertaining to the hypotheses and research questions identified in this pre-registration that we publish or present will be based on the final sample, not the interim sample downloaded for purposes of the course requirements.
registration_responses.sample: We aim to collect data from 400 participants. We have multiple predictors and the infidelity questionnaire includes 64 items. A sample size of 400 will provide enough statistical power to investigate the relationship between variables and judgements of infidelity while allowing for the examination of possible sex differences.
registration_responses.analyses:
It should be mentioned that for infidelity incidence and partner’s engagement in infidelity behaviours, participants indicate whether they or their partner have engaged in extradyadic behaviours by choosing yes or no options for each behaviour. Therefore, the infidelity incidence and partner’s engagement in infidelity behaviours will be calculated in one of the following forms: 1) to be coded as yes/no (e.g., if they’ve engaged in any of the behaviours, they get a 1 for yes) or 2) a proportion (e.g., if there are 10 behaviours and they’ve engaged in 5 of them they get a .5) or c) a count (e.g., if there are 10 behaviours and they’ve engaged in 5 they get a 5). We may change the type of analysis incorporating these variables based on the way we decide to treat these variables. But for the purpose of this application, we present the analysis as we treat these variables as dichotomous (yes/no). 
A  2 participants’ gender (men and women) × 2 timepoints (2009 and 2020) × 5 types of extradyadic behaviours mixed method ANOVA will be used to test the differences between severity ratings from 2020 data and 2009 data.
Loglinear analysis will be used to compare infidelity incidence rates in 2009 and 2020 based on gender (RQ2).
We will conduct a 2 timepoint (2009 vs 2020) × 2 participants’ gender (men vs women) between-subject ANOVA to investigate differences between men’s and women’s sociosexuality scores in 2020 and 2009 (RQ3). 

Hierarchical multiple regression analysis will be used to investigate how well the various individual difference measures predict severity ratings, controlling for gender of the participant (H1). Gender will be entered in step one and all the predictors will be included in step two. 
Logistic regression analysis will be used to investigate how well the various individual difference measures predict infidelity incidence, controlling for the gender of the participants (H2).  Gender will be entered in step one and all the predictors will be included in step two. 

Simple mediation, using the PROCESS macro, or SEM (structural equation modeling) will be used to test whether use of monogamy maintenance strategies mediates the relationship between commitment and infidelity incidence (RQ4) with gender as a covariate. 

We will conduct a 2 participants’ sex (man vs women) × 2 sex of the extradyadic partner (same vs opposite) × 5 types of extradyadic behaviours mixed method ANOVA to investigate differences in severity ratings based on participants’ sex and extradyadic partners’ sex. 


Logistic regression will be used to test whether honesty humility moderates the association between sociosexual orientation and infidelity incidence, controlling for gender of the participants (H6).

The associations in RQ5 and RQ6 will be investigated using simple Pearson correlation (for two continuous variables) or Chi square (for two categorical variables).
registration_responses.outliers:
Participants who report they have never been involved in a romantic relationship will be removed from the analysis. 
Additionally, we asked a self-report response data quality question at the end of the study in 2020 in which participants are asked to indicate whether we ought to keep their data given the attention and effort they put into completing the survey. We will exclude the data from any participant who reports lack of attention (i.e., who responds “no”). 
Also, at the end of the survey in 2020, we ask participants for their permission to retain the data for use in our analyses. We will delete their data if they choose not to let us use their data.
After excluding data based on above criteria, we will run our analysis both with and without outliers. We will report whether the results differ in any publications and presentations. Outliers will be identified by computing the overall standard deviation and removing any outliers beyond 3.0 SD above/below the mean.
registration_responses.dependent:
In the current study, we will present 64 extradyadic behaviours to participants and will ask them to:

·	Indicate whether they would consider the behaviour to be unfaithful or cheating if an individual in a serious committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviours with a person of the opposite sex.
·	Rate the severity for each of the behaviors assuming a partner in a serious, committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviors with an opposite sex partner.
·	Indicate whether they would consider the behaviour to be unfaithful or cheating if an individual in a serious committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviours with a person of the same sex.
·	Rate each behavior for severity if a partner in a serious, committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviors with a same sex partner.
·	Check any of the behaviors they have engaged in with someone other than their partner while in a serious committed relationship (either a prior relationship or their current relationship).
·	Check any of the behaviors that a partner in a serious, committed relationship with them has engaged in with someone else (either in a prior relationship or their current relationship).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The current research is a follow up to another study that was done 10 years ago (2009). In that study, we presented 53 extra-dyadic behaviours to participants and asked them to:

·	Indicate whether they would consider the behaviour to be unfaithful or cheating if an individual in a serious committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviours with a person of the opposite sex.
·	Rate the severity for each of the behaviors assuming a partner in a serious, committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviors with an opposite sex partner.
·	Indicate whether they would consider the behaviour to be unfaithful or cheating if an individual in a serious committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviours with a person of the same sex.
·	Rate each behavior for severity if a partner in a serious, committed dating relationship engaged in these behaviors with a same sex partner.
·	Check any of the behaviors they have engaged in with someone other than their partner while in a serious committed relationship (either a prior relationship or their current relationship).
·	Check any of the behaviors that a partner in a serious, committed relationship with them has engaged in with someone else (either in a prior relationship or their current relationship).
One major goal of the current study is to investigate how much people’s answers to these questions have changed after 10 years. The main reason we expect we might see changes in how people perceive extra-dyadic behaviours (i.e., how severe they perceive them) and how much they engage in the behaviours is related to changes in technology. Increasing use of smartphones in the past decade, the prevalence of dating applications and websites such as Tinder, and new ways of sending text messages such as direct messaging on social media or messaging applications might have influenced how people perceive and engage in extra-dyadic behaviours (e.g. by providing new media or platforms with which to engage in infidelity). 

For the same reason, we included more online and technology-related items (i.e., behaviours) in our follow up study to make our list of possible extradyadic behaviours more comprehensive. To decide which items from the list of 53 behaviours to keep and which to discard for the follow-up, we presented the 53 behaviours to participants in a study in 2019 and asked them to make the same judgements as participants did in the 2009 study. Based on the results of this study, we dropped the behaviours that fewer than 10 percent of participants in the 2019 study identified as infidelity and replaced them with (a) new online and technology-related behaviours and (b) several behaviours that other researchers identified in their studies during the ten years since our 2009 study (i.e., those not included in our previous list). Combined, this process resulted in an updated list including 64 extradyadic behaviours that we will use in the current follow up study. 

In the 2019 study, we also asked participants to sort the 53 behaviours into categories (via a card sort task). We will use the results of a cluster analysis performed on these data to categorize the behaviours in the present study so that we can run our analyses on the infidelity categories instead of each behaviour separately (thereby reducing the number of statistical tests we will need to perform). The four categories that emerged from the card sort task are (1) sexual behaviours, (2) emotional behaviours, (3) ambiguous behaviours (such as doing a favour for someone or spending time with them) , and (4) others (we haven’t found a label that captures the range of items in this category so we might change the name of the category if we find a suitable name). The behaviours in the follow up study will be classified into the same categories plus an additional category for online behaviours. However, we might change the categories if the results of reliability tests show that the items in the same category are not coherent. 

In the follow up study (the current research), we will present the list of 64 extra-dyadic behaviours to our participants and ask them to make the same judgements as participants in the 2009 study did. Our hypotheses and research questions are presented below. For each hypothesis or set of related hypotheses a rationale that supports anticipated direction is presented. Also, in the following sections, participants’ own engagement in extradyadic behaviours will be referred to as “infidelity incidence” ,their ratings of perceived severity of the extradaydic behaviours will be referred to as “severity ratings”, and their partners’ engagement in extradyadic behaviours will be called “partner’s engagement in extradyadic behaviours.”

Research question 1) Will severity ratings for the various types of infidelity in the current study differ from severity ratings in the study in 2009? We will examine the difference across timepoints for the sample as a whole, as well as incorporating gender of participant and gender of extradyadic partner into the analysis.

Research question 2) Will the reported incidence of different types of infidelity reported in the current study differ from the reported incidence of infidelity in 2009? We will examine the difference across timepoints for the sample as a whole, as well as incorporating gender of participant into the analysis.

Research question 3) Will partner engagement in different types of infidelity reported in the current study differ from reported partner engagement in infidelity in 2009? We will examine the difference across timepoints for the sample as a whole, as well as incorporating gender of participant into the analysis.


Research question 4) Do 2020 participants differ from 2009 participants in their mean score on sociosexuality? We will examine the difference across timepoints for the sample as a whole, as well as incorporating gender of participant into the analysis.


Hypothesis 1) Controlling for possible gender differences, higher severity ratings will be associated with: 1) higher attachment anxiety, 2) higher honesty-humility (HH), 3) higher jealousy, 4) lower attachment avoidance, 5) lower infidelity incidence, 6) more restricted sociosexual orientation. 

Hypothesis 2) Controlling for possible gender differences, higher infidelity incidence will be associated with: 1) higher attachment anxiety, 2) higher attachment avoidance, 3) more unrestricted sociosexual orientation, 4) higher quality of alternatives, 5) lower HH, 6) lower commitment, 7) lower relationship satisfaction, 8) lower investment size.

Rationale for hypotheses 1 and 2:

With regards to honesty humility, results of a study by Bourdage, Lee, Ashton, and Perry (2007) show that higher honesty-humility is positively correlated with relationship exclusivity. Based on this evidence, we hypothesized that since people with high honesty humility value relationship exclusivity, they will tend to rate infidelity behaviours more severe and engage in infidelity behaviours less often than people who are low in honesty humility. 

Research shows that attachment insecurity can be a predictor of engaging in infidelity, and therefore we hypothesized that higher attachment insecurity (both anxious and avoidant) is associated with higher infidelity incidence. However, the predicted association between attachment insecurity and severity ratings differs based on the type of attachment insecurity. This anticipated difference is related to perceived levels of threat in anxious vs avoidant individuals.  Anxious individuals are prone to overestimate threats to their romantic relationship (Collins, 1996) and they experience more jealousy in comparison to less anxious individuals (Buunk, 1997; Guerrero, 1998; Radecki-Bush, Farrell, and Bush, 1993; Sharpsteen and Kirkpatrick, 1997). Therefore, we expected higher severity ratings for anxious participants. 
In contrast, avoidant individuals show low levels of concern about the threat of a rival (Guerrero, 1998; Sharpsteen and Kirkpatrick, 1997). In current study, we expect that highly avoidant individuals will perceive lower levels of threat when evaluating extradyadic behaviours and therefore, they will score low on severity ratings. 

In addition, research shows that people with unrestricted sociosexual orientation tend to perceive extradyadic behaviours as less indicative of infidelity in comparison to people with more restricted sociosexual orientation (Mattingly, Wilson, Clark, Bequette, & Weidler, 2010) which is consistent with our anticipated direction of the relationship between severity ratings and sociosexual orientation. Unrestricted sociosexual orientation is also a facilitator of engaging in infidelity (Fincham and May, 2016. Therefore, we anticipated that participants with unrestricted sociosexual orientation would report higher rates of infidelity incidence.

We also hypothesized that a high level of jealousy might lead people to perceive extradyadic behaviours as more threatening and, therefore, that we will find an association between increasing jealousy and higher scores on severity ratings.

Our hypotheses regarding the Investment Model variables are based on previous research indicating that people with lower relationship commitment, lower relationship satisfaction, lower investment size, and higher quality of alternatives tend to consider extradyadic behaviours as infidelity to a lower degree (Mattingly, Wilson, Clark, Bequette, & Weidler, 2010) and to report higher rates of engaging in infidelity (Drigotas, Safstrom, & Gentilia, 1999; Fincham and May, 2016).. 

Finally, previous infidelity experience predicts future engagement in infidelity (Fincham and May, 2016). Based on this evidence, we hypothesized that people who have engaged in extradyadic behaviours will evaluate them as less severe than people who have not engaged in such behaviours and that might partially explain why they tend to engage in the infidelity more often in the future. 

Research question 4) Does the use of monogamy maintenance strategies predict infidelity incidence and if so, is this relationship mediated by any of the investment model variables and does it hold equally for both genders?


Hypothesis 3) men will perceive sexual infidelity as less severe when their partner engages in it with a same- rather than opposite-sex extra-dyadic partner.

Hypothesis 4) Women’s ratings of the perceived severity of sexual infidelity will not vary as a function of the gender of the extra-dyadic partner.

We hypothesized that male participants would judge sexual extra-dyadic behaviours less severe if their partner engaged in these behaviours with a same- rather than opposite-sex partner because women’s same-sex sexual contact poses no threat to paternity certainty and is portrayed in pornography as sexually arousing for men. We predicted that gender of the extra-dyadic partner would not influence perceived severity of infidelity behaviours among women since the threat that the partner might divert resources to another may be equally high regardless of the gender of the EDP.

Hypothesis 5) in both studies (2009 and 2020) men will report higher rates of engaging in infidelity than women. 

Several studies show that men report higher rates of infidelity than women   (e.g., Atkins et al., 2001; Buunk & Bakker, 1995; Choi et al., 1994; Treas & Giesen, 2000; for a meta-analysis, see Petersen & Hyde, 2010).


Hypothesis 6) The relationship between sociosexual orientation and infidelity incidence will be moderated by HH, such that those with unrestricted sociosexual orientation who are also low in HH will be more likely to report having engaged in extradyadic behaviours than people who score high on both variables. We will include gender of participant in this analysis. 

Research shows that an unrestricted attitude toward sex is one of the predictors of infidelity incidence (Fincham and May, 2016). Research also indicates that higher HH scores are associated with higher relationship exclusivity (Bourdage et al., 2007). Therefore, people who are unrestricted in their sociosexual orientation might engage in extradyadic behaviours less if they score high on HH (in comparison those who are sociosexually unrestricted and low on honesty humility). 

Research indicates that higher HH scores are associated with higher relationship exclusivity (Bourdage et al., 2007), so we are predicting that high HH might serve to inhibit, to some extent, those with an unrestricted sociosexual orientation from engaging in infidelity compared with those who are both unrestricted and low in HH (and therefore not much inclined to worry about  relationship exclusivity).

Research question 5) Are reports of a partner’s engagement in extradyadic behaviours associated with 1) severity ratings, 2) relationship satisfaction, 4) jealousy, 5) investment size, 6) relationship commitment, and 7) quality of alternatives?

Research question 6) We will explore possible associations between a) jealousy and infidelity incidence, b) the investment model variables (commitment, investment size, quality of alternatives, relationship satisfaction) and severity ratings, e) infidelity incidence (i.e., participants’ own reports of having engaged in extradyadic behaviours) and (their reports of) partner’s engagement in extradyadic behaviours.

attributes.title: The Try to bring Light into the Darkness: To the Connection of the Dark Tetrad, Optimism and Gratitude

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The Try to bring Light into the Darkness: To the Connection of the Dark Tetrad, Optimism and Gratitude

sample.value: In any case over 133 people should participate.

analyses.value: In order to test the seven hypotheses and the research question, Pearson's correlation coefficient is used.

outliers.value:
Questionnaires that have not been completely processed are removed and if control questions are not answered correctly, the data are deleted.
Also, if the processing time deviates two standard deviations from the mean.

dependent.value:
The study contains six constructs, the dark tetrad (narcissism, machiavellianism, psychopathy & everyday sadism), gratitude and optimism. Which are measured as follows: 

The dark tetrad is measured using the Short dark Triad questionnaire (SD3, German version) (Malesza, Ostaszewski, Büchner, & Kaczmarek, 2017) and the Comprehensive assessment of sadistic tendencies (CAST) for everyday sadism (Buckels & Paulhus, 2013).

Gratitude is measured by using the Gratitude Questionnaire-Six Item Form (German version; Blabst, Morgan, & Lermer, 2019). 

Optimism is evaluated by using the German version of the Life-Orientation-Test (LOT-R) for dispositional optimism and pessimism (Glaesmer, Hoyer, Klotsche, & Herzberg, 2008)

conditions.value:
One condition: Participants should be at least 18 years old 
The scientific theoretical approach is quantitative, and it is an empirical study based on a correlative design. The time of investigation is a cross section.

hypothesis.value:
The main question is: Which connections between the dark tetrad, optimism and gratitude are there?
The study examines seven hypothesis and one research question:

Hypothesis 1: Narcissism correlates positively with optimism
Hypothesis 2: Machiavellianism correlates negatively with optimism 
Hypothesis 3: Psychopathy correlates negatively with optimism 
Hypothesis 4: Everyday sadism correlates negatively with optimism

Hypothesis 5: Machiavellianism correlates negatively with gratitude 
Hypothesis 6: Psychopathy correlates negatively with gratitude
Hypothesis 7: Everyday sadism correlates negatively with gratitude

Research question 1: How is narcissism associated with gratitude?

attributes.title: UniSiegenExP2020 - Influence of Pictograms in Package Leaflets on Memory Performance
attributes.description: This is a project page of an ExPra-group at the Department of Psychology at the University of Siegen, Germany (2019-2020, supervising lecturer of this research group is Prof. Dr. Julia Haberstroh). This ExPra subgroup is part of the Group 4B. The general research topic is the examination if the understanding of information is influenced by the type of information presentation in the written information about medical measures. This subgroup delas with the issue "Influence of Pictograms in Package Leaflets on Memory Performance".

q1.value: Influence of Pictograms in Package Leaflets on Memory Performance

q2.value: Esther Blum , Nik Hulsmans, Katharina Apel, Jasmine Daphne Heidecke, Julia Haberstroh

q3.value:
Based on the dual-coding theory this study investigates whether the presentation of medical information with certain pictograms in a package leaflet has an effect on the recall of this information.  
This study is conducted by bachelor psychology students as part of the seminar "Experimentalpraktikum" of the University Siegen.

q4.value: The presentation of medical information with certain pictograms in a package leaflet has a positive effect on the retrieval of this information, compared to the presentation of medical information without pictograms in a conventional package leaflet.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-over-within-subject-design with Group A and Group B. The pictograms in the package leaflet will be presented in position 1 for group A and position 2 for group B.

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two predetermined blocks (Group A or Group B).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the subject registration platform "sona" and a snowball system. Participation is voluntary. Participants must be at least 18 years old and are not allowed to be impaired in their cognitive functions.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 84 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 100, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of 0.4 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: We will terminate our data collection on 31.03.2020 at 23:59 (UTC +01:00) due to time limitations in our ExPra-Group or if we recruit 100 participants.

question.value: We manipulated the position of the pictograms in the package leaflet. The two levels of this categorial variable are: pictograms presented on position 1 for group A and position 2 for group B.

The variable we will measure is the recall influenced by the different presented information. This will be evaluated by the single-choice questionnaire. 
The questionnaire consists of 12 questions, with six questions referring to information presented with pictograms and six questions referring to information presented without pictograms. 
Ten questions have four options, only one of which is correct. Two questions have two options, again only one of which is correct.

We will take the mean of the recall performance for information presented with and without pictograms. 
A further description of our analysis can be found in the "Analysis Plan" section.

First we will calculate a chi-square test to determine whether there is a statistically significant difference between Group A and Group B. 
The data of Group A and Group B will be merged and splitted in "recall based on information with pictogram" and "recall based on information without pictogram". Then we will use a two-tailed paired samples t-test within the groups to compare the "recall based on information with pictogram" and "recall based on information without pictogram". 
To calculate the effect size we will use Cohen's d.

q20.value: The recall performance does not require any additional transformation. We will compare correct and false recall for information presented with and without pictograms.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the two-tailed paired sample t-test suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: Outliers will only be excluded if they are 3 standard deviations under the mean.

q23.value: Subjects will not be included in the analysis if they ended the questionnaire prematurely.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to recall performance. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender and educational level) and the performance in the recall of medical information with or without pictograms.
